title: Do you want to live to 100? - Quora

response.answer_text: Clearly as things currently stand I would imagine that commonsense is you want to check out before you reach the stage of becoming dysfunctional and in extreme pain with no quality and at 100 or more not many people are what you could term very functional, in your 80s and early 90s it might be OK, for example my uncle is 83 and still traveling long haul with a trip every month to somewhere, Arizona last month, Tenerife next month and the Bahamas currently for two weeks, frankly even I would be exhausted by his routine. His life in his 80s is still great and he uses an iPhone, iPad etc and is always learning and planning, his only fear is it ending! As a point of interest I just flew two days ago from my house in Germany to my home in Fort Lauderdale and even in business class find it an ordeal! It’s not a physical ordeal I just don’t enjoy it and neither does my girlfriend who is 20 years younger than me so my uncle proves in some ways age not that relevant but by 100 almost everyone will be struggling. As a researcher into aging I am often asked to define what aging is so here is my definition - Aging is the progressive and inexorable accumulation of molecular and cellular damage which leads to loss of physical function increasing infirmity, elevated risk of chronic illness, and ultimately death -. Once we address those issues by repairing the accumulated damage we will be pretty much home and dry and living a long life will no longer automatically go hand in hand with infirmity and suffering. Throughout our history if there has been a route by which we can lead healthier, happier and more productive lives we have tended to take it and that is the reason why anti-aging medicine will progress down exactly the same route and why arguments such as we are interfering with nature, it’s morally wrong etc simply do not have any validity at all. As soon as we had the means, historically we have tackled all of the diseases which tended to kill people, for example, polio, smallpox — which used to kill millions. Infections which were one of the main killers before we had antibiotics because you must keep in mind that people could simply cut themselves while they were working in their backyard or women could suffer an infection during childbirth, which would kill both her and the baby. Even worse, something simple such as an infected finger or toe could lead to amputation of the whole hand or foot because there was no other route to bring the infection under control, even that frequently didn't work because there was no way that you could actually prevent infection which could arise from the amputation itself. These days not only are there antibiotics but we have retroviral drugs to tackle AIDS, we have insulin to manage diabetes, Ace inhibitors and beta-blockers to tackle high blood pressure, the list is endless. Add in all the surgical procedures such as cataract surgery, new joints and all sorts of other interventions such as cardiac surgery, for example, a heart bypass or stents which increase the person's quality of life and the trend is pretty obvious. As soon as we can bring aging under a decisive level of clinical control, clearly we will. The most bizarre thing in my mind is that we seem to try and tackle the main diseases of aging such as cancer, heart disease, stroke, Alzheimer’s, diabetes, arthritis and neurodegenerative diseases individually but what we seem to fail to grasp is we're not actually attacking the root cause which is aging itself we are simply attacking the end result. Tackle aging and you would inevitably address the diseases of aging because these conditions mainly affect old people and do not frequently strike at the young. We don't know at this stage exactly how far off the first effective anti-aging therapies are but what we can reasonably assume is they are probably no less than 10 years away and probably not much more than 30 years so for many people alive now being confronted with many of the diseases of aging will not arise because the conditions will be under a decisive level of biomedical control. My final comment is that once aging is under a decisive level of medical control I will opt for as many years as I can get but 500 might do for starters and when I get to 500 in the middle of this century I will take it from there, call me greedy but I reckon I would want more :-)

author_info.name: Bharadajava Atri Jogesh Charaka Bhakta Krishnamurti Suraj Hendrickson

response.answer_text: (Disclaimer. I DID have the post be something different it, but I edited it to look better) Yes, I do, actually. And here’s why My relatives will miss me less since I’ll live longerMy friends as wellI’ll have more time to have fun in this life until I am reincarnated againMy plan to live to 100 or 110, is great. Most weekdays (except Friday), I shall follow this diet (changes may be needed on US Federal holidays. Like Independence day or Thanksgiving). 9 cups of water a day. For Breakfast, an avocado, a garlic bud with a bit of cloves, and 3 Brazil nuts. For lunch, a tomato, a yogurt container, and green beans. For dinner, a cup of yogurt, and rice with coconut oil. Laughing (lower stress and blood pressure), a cup of coffee with turmeric and cinnamon mixed in a day, meditate and do yoga, and get sunlight in moderation. On Friday, my diet will be different. For breakfast, I'll have a cup of milk, a plate of kale with vinegar and a bit of grapefruit slices, for lunch, nuts and a bit of date palm, and for dinner, a bowl of Thyme & basil covered with canola oil. As well as avoiding smoking or alcoholic drinks, as both are addictive. This is because getting smoke through lungs is a fast way to get effects going. So, when I'm stressed, I'll just exercise instead. I'll avoid prescription drugs unless as a last resort in order to prevent side effects, and I'll treat it naturally with fruits, vegetables, water, essential oils, herbs, spices, and tea. When I reach my 40's, I'll replace milk with water, to lower calories, fat and cholesterol. And instead of chocolate cake on my birthdays, I'll have carob cake. Carob is a plant found in Arabia, Israel and Turkey. It is like chocolate, but has less calories, more fiber, calcium and potassium, less sugar, but also less iron, and NO caffeine. For exercise, I'll walk a mile a day, and visit the gym 3 times a week. Now, the holiday meals4th of July-For snacks, watermelon slices and baked potatoes. Other than that, my style of vegetarian breakfast for dinner type night. Breakfast burrito with jalapeno pepper slices, Spanish rice, and black pepper, and instead of syrup for the waffles, it'll be honey mixed with turmeric (as honey has less calories than syrup, and 1 tablespoon of turmeric has 15% of DV Iron, and has been shown to prevent Alzheimer's and skin cancer)

I want to live that long so long as I am in reasonably good health, able to look after myself for the most part, meaning to get to the table, get to the bathroom, enjoy reading a book or talking with friends and so forth. And I have a good to excellent chance of making it, because I’m in excellent health at this time, taken all around, and I’m doing all the right things in terms of diet, exercise, family, etc. I’ve given up all my bad habits that lead to early death, such as riding motorcycles and drinking more than an ounce of alcohol once in a while. That small an amount is apparently not a serious risk. My chances are good to excellent because all my known direct ancestors, other than my mother, lived into their late eighties or nineties,excepting the ones that were killed in accidents of one sort or another, and Mom made it into her early eighties. A number of close relatives have made it past the century mark. IF she had been under the long term care of a COMPETENT physician, she would easily have made it into her nineties as well. But she developed diabetes in her middle age or maybe even younger, and it wasn’t diagnosed by ANY of three different physicians until we got a fourth one when she was already old. So I’ve hit the genetic lottery in terms of living a long life, and I’m counting on drawing a couple of good cards by way of advancing medical knowledge as well.

I personally don’t want to live to be 100. You know why? I don’t want to be so old that I’m not able to do anything anymore because I don’t have all my physical or mental resources anymore. I don’t want to lose my memory or my eyesight and not be able to drive or cook, and have to live in a skilled nursing home. I wouldn’t like it if I had to receive daily attention or be with people all the time either. That would make me feel suffocated. Plus, I think the people who want to live to be 100 want to do it just to say they did it once they reach that age. I’m not here to gain championship of who can live the longest. I want to just let life take its course with no definite plan about how long I want to live. Plus, life is just more effort than it’s worth to even want to live to be that old. I don’t want to work that hard to achieve that ripe old age of 100.

Honestly, no I would not like to reach 100. I don’t even like reaching my current age of 61. The reason I say that is because when you live in a world that is so Accelerated with a vibe of not really caring for one another it doesn’t really give me much hope and it doesn’t make me want to live any longer than I have to. I am very lonely I do not have support out in this violent climate of life. What friend I have Either moved on or died!! When you face each day not realizing where your next meal is coming from and you’re living within the arms of poverty, no I can honestly say I do not want to reach 100. Even those that have reached maturity or thrown into the lions den of nursing homes Where are they are mistreated and abused. Who wants that to look forward to. So, no I do not want to reach 100. If I die tomorrow that would be awesome

No. I have always imagined living into my 80’s at least, but I have never forgotten something my grandmother said. She was about 80, (in 1980), and I was trying to tell her about how computers were coming into our own homes, and she said she did not want to hear about, that it was just too much. She explained how she remembered gas lights in the streets, she saw the first cars come on to the road, the first electrical coming into homes, the advent of sound theater and then later, TV’s in the home. She watched her beloved horses fade into history. She watched 2 world wars and all the technological advances that came with that. All her knowledge, all her skills, all her experience and know how had become hobbies. For her it wasn’t the physical limitations, it wasn’t the loss of husband and friends, it was those things that had made soul tired and ready to move on. Even though I have kept up with the trend in personal computers, I am most definitely not ready to have talking machines around me. We all have lines we draw in the sand and I can see, by the time another 30 years has passed, I will be more than ready to move on.

Yes and noYes -because I want to see how the world had changed , were the things promised done ? … to see my grandkids and their children , to tell tales and feed them knowledge that is remarkableNo- because the world is no longer safe , things we've feared and encountered in our dreams have turned into reality . Some dark mysteries that could traumatize not only one but 100 people .

Yes, why not ? 100 is nothing special, the figure could be 30, 50 or 1000 without really changing my answer. The real question is about my health at that age and what I will still be able to do and not, but even if I can only tell stories it would be enough for me. Another point is of course the population pressure on the world: is it sustainable if everybody is living to 100 or older ? I can intellectually imagine that if human reproduction rate is too high compared to death rate, the earth can become even worse than now (it is probably already too high given the amount of resources people are wasting today). Anyway I’m not designed to willfully resign and end my own life just to save the world or merely leave others waste a larger share of the world. Consuming less resources is okay for my, and I’m doing that (I of course can improve).

Given my observations, I don’t think I would because I have some health issues which will just become worse as I grow older. I don’t want to be dependent to the point I have to have daily attention and can’t do the basics like eat, bathe, get out of bed, etc. That’ll happen before I’m 90 (I say optimistically), so I sure don’t want to live to 100. On the other hand, my husband’s family had many members who lived to 100 and beyond, and were active and self-sufficient. If I were blood-related to them, I might shoot for 100+.

*I try to have enough savings. I am also not the kind of guy who is aging. I also try to live this life as if it is what I will fall back to when I die. *if I get to 100 ‘ this day so you’, if I don't get to 100 ‘ this day you weren’t'…. and it continues like that if I surpass 100. *but honestly at a few over 30 years old, I am fed up of life. Suicide is s lie. It would hurt to take your own life. If I could save my money and transport to death. *I am fed up because no matter the good deed you do, you are the one best that can console yourself. Infinity of years to come, we would not have recovered from this doom of socialisation. Make the whole world now infinity years diamond and gold. Like so many lazy people lived this world and got away.

That's a pretty difficult question for me, I mean I would love to. But also I'll have to see my loved ones die/fade away. Hell,I may even see my (future) daughter/son die of natural causes and I'm still alive. But also staying alive thag long is learning and enjoying life at its fullest potential. I want to die when I accomplished my part of this world:Teaching my kids, helping people, seeing my grandsons, had my share of sorrow and happiness, or die knowing that my death will lead to/cause good scenarios My final answer is, I want to die when its my time. Even if it were now, tomorrow, 10 years from now, 80, 100.

Depends. My mum was 101 when she passed away in 2012.Up until her late eighties, she was marvellous for her age. She even chased a burglar down the+street, brandishing the knife she habitually kept under her pillow, after she woke and found him in her bedroom. After that, her eyesight deteriorated from macular degeneration. Then her hearing. Then she began the long decline into senility. She survived a minor stroke in 2008 and was able to remain in her own home, with input daily from careers and five times a week my wife and I drove the fifty- mile round trip to see her even though she was often truculent or downright abusive. I would not wish her final years on anybody. Her intellect gone, all her friends dead. No thanks, I would sooner check- out before everything goes haywire. Of course, if I can be guaranteed I will die in 32 years time not one jot or tittle worse than I am today, then, sign me up.

Personally, no. Only an incredibly small portion of the population lives to be 100. Of that population, almost everyone requires the help of someone for simple things, such as eating or using the bathroom. All of your friends (same age) will be gone. You will likely see children and grandchildren pass away if you have them, and you will become a burden on your remaining family. All for what? A few extra years? You still have to face death, and your life at that time will still feel like it passed by too fast.

Oh boy, the ultimate question!! I think, with decent health, everyone would like to live to be 100. However, our spouses would be gone, our children would be old, and we’d need help just for day to day living. Personally, I don’t want to live in a home for the aged. I’ve seen them, and I’ve smelled them. It isn’t a place where I want to live, assuming you can call it living. I believe that God has His plan for all of us. If His plan is that I live to be 100, then so be it. Maybe I still have some wisdom to impart. Who knows..cause it isn’t up to us anyway. We’ll just have to wait and see.

No use of living for 100 yrs or more ,it is better to have a life span of 70 or 75 yrs at the most,because never know what could happen in future,the days and conditions might even become worst than now at present.I would love to leave or bid adieu to this world as i would get my desires and wishes fulfilled. No use of living long life with old age body in pathetic condition,so dying after age of 60 is good and dying peacefully happily in good condition without any serious problems, without any pain is still very good because no one in this world prefers painful death.I would like to say that “leave this world as if you have slipped out of your body in a deep sleep and reached the god peacefully “.

OMG NO!!! I’ve been around 52 years and I feel that’s OLD. I can’t imagine going another 50, much less 100 more. That would mean watching all your family and friends grow old and die leaving you behind. No thanks! Also, technology is taking off at a rapid rate and although I know computers and such, the idea of a self driving car is abhorrent to me, along with AI. No… I hope to be long gone by the time those things are realized.

No. The first reason is that the time or years I will reach this age, there will be so much of pollution, specially air pollution which will cause much more severe health problems. I don't want to suffer from such diseases. Second, a human lives for himself when he is young. As he ages he starts living for others means he gives other persons priority before himself. At the age of 100, a human doesn't have energy to do stuffs with enthusiasm. Who will lie on bed doing nothing? Not me. Hope you liked this. Will meet again. @Gagan Mudgal

I don’t know if I want to be alive NOW, and you want me to stay alive another half a century?! Seriously?! Have you BEEN to a nursing home? Ever been inside one, smelled it, seen the misery on EVERYONE’S faces inside it’s dirty, dingy walls?! Because that is where the pressure is coming for us to grow that much older. It’s coming from Big Healthcare, who want us imprisoned in it’s elder facilities so they can take every last nickel we ever earned via our guilt stricken heirs. Live your life now. Make that decision to live today, because tomorrow is not guaranteed.

No thanks!!!!. I’m 80 and about had it as it is. It is hard to be my age especially when I’m all alone. Family all gone,friends al died so to go another 20 more years what for??? I don’t want to be kept alive just because my health insurance is good and some greedy institution wants to make good of my insurances?? Naahhh!! may be just one more year or so…. Not that anything can possibly change my present life anymore…. So…my answer is NO!!

Personally, I do not care one way or the other. With one exception. I do not want to spend any significant amount of time in an unhealthy state. I am currently 76 and my family history is one of longevity, I am healthy, and I lead a relatively healthy lifestyle. So, there is a good possibility that I just might live that long. But I have accomplished all of my important life goals and will continue to be productive as long as possible. “Do not go gentle into that good night.”

“Do you want to live to 100+?” I know it’s something which is totally out of my control. But my answer is a YES. Why? Because I don’t know why I was born in the first place then why would I wish to die younger.I want to learn more, see more, taste more, love more, hear more and travel all around the world. Don’t be fooled by anyone who says “NO” to this question. All of them have dreams inside their heads and no one will wish to leave all of that behind without seeing the results.No doubt, there is nothing sweeter than life itself. It’s full of mysteries; we don’t know whence we came and when we will leave this world. Good luck!…hope this helps. Thank U for the A2A too.

No. I would sooner enjoy my youth and sacrifice my later years. After all, by leading a healthy and unadventurous life one is only adding years on at the wrong end - one cannot have a second childhood, so I'd rather enjoy the one I do have and perhaps live unhealthily and knock a few years off at the end. I know lots of very active 100+ year-olds, but ultimately they are not as active as I am now. I would not object to reaching 100 in itself if I did happen to achieve it, but I would ensure that I would still be doing as much as a 100-year-old could possibly do.

It is very likely that people who teenagers now, or children, will live to be 100. Life expectancy has been increasing consistently (in vast majority of places) for a long time. The people who are living to 80–90 now were born in the 1940’s. So it is not so much a question of whether you want to, as you may not have a choice, unless you decide to end your life early.

I had a 97 year old patient once who said she wished she would just die, because everyone she knew and cared about was already gone. This stuck with me, and I wondered how many people wanted a long life because they’re scared to die? I want to live long enough to enjoy some retirement years. Maybe I’d be happy with 80 years, assuming these are 80 reasonably healthy years. But I’m not going to get greedy about it.

Sort of. Let me explain… I would probably see a lot of my friends and family die, which wouldn't be very nice, and I would also feel guilty that I was still healthy while they were becoming sick. However, I would be able to spend more time with my children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren (maybe even great, great grandchildren by that age). I think this would reduce my pain and suffering.

I am witnessing my mother’s very slow, very distressing decline at the age of 98. Based on her experience (no, she doesn’t really want to be alive any more) I’d say no … not if entails what she’s going through at the moment. Yet there are plenty of extremely sprightly centenarians who make you think it might be OK. And of course medical advances make it more likely that by the time I reach 100, life will be easier for old people. Nevertheless I don’t really think I want to last that long. That said, at what point does one opt to stop?

No, but given technological breakthrough’s it may not matter what i think, by 2070 genetic splicing, CRISPR discovery breakthroughs, & understanding of the human genome is a game changer. Moore’s Law has seen remarkable feats in technological leaps as a result of 3 decades, Double that and you have 2/3rds of a persons life, meaning that an individual will live in 3 to 4 waves of Moores law. Each being lightyears away from the others. I’e, Internet,post-internet,Now peak of the information age. it will not be a matter of if, but rather

I cannot imagine being 100! I’m too vain and doubt what I would have to offer my family or myself. Healthwise , would I be a burden? Or perhaps spend it wasting away in a nursing home. No, I would prefer to die before I’ve outlived my usefulness. I’m 77 and 10 more years is plenty to accomplish what I need to do to complete my journey in this life.

It is like you have to express the time. It doesn't matter how much you live ,the matter is how much you enjoy it Just make your present time best and do every day like this gone be your last Don't push for anything because when you push yourself it is like you don't want to do it Yes these line are seems to from movies but it's true. And yes I want to live hundred of years to fullfill my dreams because there and many things that I want to do , i think hundred years is not even sufficient

When I was a child I would have said yes. Now at 70 the thought of another 30 years would worry me. My life has answered pretty well all the questions I ever had. I have read every book that I particularly wanted to (there are obviously occasional new ones to think about). I have travelled enough of the globe not to be concerned about countries I might have missed. I have watched my children grow to maturity and need no further help from me. Having achieved all I set out to achieve in life I do not want to have to wait 30 more years before I am finally allowed to roll over and go to sleep.

Well, if I could live on at my present state of health (or maybe even better), WHY NOT? This would mean pushing 160, by the way.Unfortunately, barring some really dramatic breakthrough in medicine, it is somewhat unlikely that I live far beyond 80 as my father died at age 73, and my grandparents at my fathers side at age 68, and at 78 at my mothers side (yes, no intersex difference in both cases). My mother, fortunately, is 82 as of now and healthy.Medicine is better than it used to be. Also, I have never smoked, unlike my grandfathers and my father. And I am only slightly overweight at a BMI of around 27. Still, no way to 160 ;-(

Actually i want to live to be 150 or even 200 years old. With all the new things we are learning today it makes it more possible to live to a very old age and still have a good life. Meditation, Yoga, Tai Chi, Qi Gong, living a healthy and stress free lifestyle can also definitely help in the longevity process. But so can the human will to survive and thrive in all aspects of our life. I do think people live a lot longer then we do now in ancient days. But one of the things to do is find out how they did it and see if we can replicate it today with the same results.

Well, actually, YOU are the one who should want me to live as long as possible. Once I'm gone, this universe, everyone in it, indeed, every particle of matter and calorie of energy will vanish from existence. All that is, ever was, and ever will be springs forth from the unimaginably infinite singularity of my consciousness.

Yes, but … I am 64 years old and parts of my body are already not up to modern living … Would i want to live another 100 years as a 26 year old - definitely Would i want to live another 100 years as a 64 year old - probably It all depends on the quality of that life from here on out.

At age 91 going on 92 I look towards the future one year at a time and would like to keep on doing so unless life becomes unbearably painful. My present objective is to survive at least until the arrival of my first great grandchild and there isn’t one on the way yet.

To be honest I’m now close to 70 . The body is starting to wear out . My mind is still very healthy and active . Mentally speaking , I have locked up my age at 56 [ when I retired ] . I purposely engage my mind in what I hope to be , meaningful thought processes . In that regard I believe I am ok . I’m sure I can reach 80 ; at best , perhaps 85 .. After that , I’m sure , physically speaking , I would be very near the end. To prolong the 80 or 85 to the 100 which you have suggested as a target , I think would be unattainable for me because being active is a target daily for me and to have that part of me compromised , I don’t believe would allow me to remain happy with my existence anymore .

Depends entirely on the way in which I ‘live’ to be a hundred! It also depends on my friends and my family and whether they too -or at least some of them - will survive that long. Would hate to be the last one standing! Having said that, the centenarian I know well is very happy to have made the ‘ton’ and got her card from the Queen - and very nice it is, too! So, if I survive that long and can live like Jean, then I would have no hesitation in saying yes. Were I to end up for years in a care home, unable to look after myself, then categorically NO!

If I were to be as healthy and active as my mother, who is 99 1/2, I would. She goes to the gym several times a week, drives, socializes almost every day, teaches handcrafts to younger people, organizes activities at her church. She is a vital, active person. And the world is better because of her.

Sure, however, it won't be long until we are able to choose digital immortality. The recent accomplishment of connecting brains to share thoughts is a major step towards connecting a human brain to a digital network. After this, it shouldn't take long to fully transfer consciousness into a virtual reality simulation. We can then completely separate ourselves from a physical body, and continue enjoying life without age-related issues.

Yes. It's to prove my (perceived) enemies wrong, mainly. Anyway, we'll all die eventually soon. With such a goal, I just have to work and be disciplined to keep myself very healthy as long as I can. I see no point reaching over 100 years if I will just be cursed by my infirmities.

Probably not. I have a very satisfying & happy life. Largely the result of a never-ending love affair with my wife. If I live to be 100 there is a very high probability that I will be without her & I just don’t want to go there.

100! Why stop there? (I’m 92) 110 seems like a modest goal to pick. I expect to revise it upwards when reached. My goal is to be the last WWII combat infantryman alive! 100 seems right around the corner. I’m just hoping society holds up as long as I do.

Yes. Why not? This isn't a case of “less is more”, because you can still have an amazing life and when you're 100, you can still live a pretty good life with the right mindset. I'm 25 now and living healthy and intend to stay that way… but either way why would you want to die, when you can live?

Yes, but only if my health is roughly as good as it is now. I’m currently 64; and, according to my doctor, I’m healthier than most people half my age. Life is great! I’ll take a lot more of that, thank you very much.

Q: Would you want to live past 100? A: Hells yes, I want to live forever. I want to meet my descendants two thousand years down the road. I’d like to see mankind finally either get it’s shit together and spread to the stars, or see how we obliterate ourselves for good. More importantly, maybe if I live to be a million years old, I’ll get to see a new season of Firefly.

The last person I asked if he was going to try to make 100 said, no, it's too much trouble. Then, within a year, he was dead unexpectedly from an illness. He might have been right about there being a point at which more time isn't worthwhile, but I think that it's better to have a century too much than a minute too little. Sign me up for 100.

no. I have lots of experience dealing with people in their 90s and a few centenarians including a couple who were still pretty perky but the majority fade seriously by the mid 90s if not before and I do not want that for me or my loved ones.

Dear Age Brilliantly No, my wish had always been to die in my 60ies. I would love to go early because of all these things which could come towards us - dementia - alzheimers - arthritis - etc. - NO fun - that is why early seems better to me. And i have 8.5 years to around get there. And no, i have not told anyone. Just to you ;)

Why 100+ and not 300+? There is no difference in how many years we live, but how do we live. There is an expression through a question. Do you want to live long and having a bad life or short and having a good life? Than you may choose between a donkey and a pig. We have to do what we came here to do and if that is taking more than a life, because most likely it would, that be it. We should just live happy and enjoy and fulfill our life. That is all.

I will forever lament the passing of my stunningly good looks and be eternally sad to no longer be the object of desire to millions of young men, but if the choice is going to be between old age and death I think I'll settle for the former, thanks.
Yes, because I have a 9-year old daughter (I'm 71 soon). But it depends what you mean by "live". To just stay alive - no. But to be able to still function as an older human being. Yes (In principle).

It would be 16 more years for me. I have four friends who are 100 to 103… all reasonsbly healthy and very sharp. One still drives, daily. Living in our CCRC means it is not that unusual. Yeah… I’d like to reach 100.

I never thought of living up to 100+. I learnt that each and every life which comes to this planet earth will surely face death and it is a fact and I must beleive it. Also it is written in the holy Quran that “ Kullu Nafsin Zaiqatul Mout” Each living thing will taste death. I wish and I pray to Almighty that whatever period I am destined to live in this beautiful world I want to live healthy without being a burden to anyone.
No, but with all the BAD luck I have been getting in recent years, I probably will still be hear to see my century out, but it is still a long way off.
Of course. If I could do so with reasonably good health, I'd want to live to 1000.
Is it really in our control?Even if it would be possible to decide our death,ITS NOT THE TIME SPENT BUT THE WORK WE DO AND HAPPINESS WE DERIVE OUT OF IT THAT MATTERS.
I don’t want to live beyond the age that I can still contribute. Once I’m no longer writing, cooking, taking care of the people I love, I’m ready to check-out.
Depends. If I’m not able to wipe my own rear unattended, then bury me, please. I want to live as long as possible with my dignity intact.
No as have to save more amount of money to survive at that age, by screwing current good time.
An arbitrary age number means nothing to me. What remains my priority is my mental, physical and cognitive health necessary look after myself.
I would not want to live past 100 because I see a marked decline in people who are 92 and older. I like to feel in control of my life.
Well I would not but I God says you are going to live to 100 you are going to live to hundred
LOL People in their 50s or 60s or even 70s may answer no. Ask them again when they are 99.
No. Definitely not. Cost of living, having to depend on others to take care of me.. no
I want to live as long as I am as healthy as I am right now.
No thanks. I think around 37 is enough for me. Life has been good so lets end on a high note.
